{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Three-Mode Imaginary\u2010Time Filtering for GHZ\u2083 Entanglement Swapping\n\nAbstract: We present a photonic protocol that embeds the genuinely nonunitary three\u2010mode imaginary\u2010time evolution operator K\u221dexp[\u2013\u03b2(\u03c3\u2093\u2297\u03c3\u1d67\u2297\u03c3_z)] for the target Hamiltonian H\u2083 directly into a three\u2010party GHZ entanglement swap at the relay node. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Three-Photon GHZ Basis Analyzer via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel Interferometry\n\nMini-abstract: We present a fully passive silicon-photonic circuit\u2014an On-Chip Three-Photon GHZ Basis Analyzer via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel interferometry\u2014that projects three unknown single-photon qubits onto the tripartite GHZ basis (|000\u27e9\u00b1|111\u27e9)/\u221a2 using only integrated waveguides, 50\u223650 beam splitters, three SPDC-sourced Bell-pair ancillas and number-resolving detectors without any active feed-forward. This novel static linear-optics supermap paves the way for scalable on-chip multiparty entanglement analysis, enabling quantum-network tasks such as conference key distribution and secret sharing directly in silicon.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Floquet-Walk Entanglement-Swap Measurement of Topological Winding in a 1D Synthetic Photonic Band\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a Floquet-walk entanglement-swap measurement of a dynamical topological order parameter in a one-dimensional synthetic photonic band by injecting Bell-pair photons into a discrete-time quantum-walk lattice of beam splitters and phase shifters.  By performing Bell-state projections between time-evolved modes at layers k and N\u2013k and recording the swapped correlation rates as k is varied, one directly reconstructs the Floquet winding number using only linear-optical elements and post-selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. By conditioning on simultaneous triple Bell\u2010state measurement heralds at node B and applying majority\u2010vote decoding at node C, the scheme concentrates the phase coherence of the target qubit state |0\u27e9+e^{i\u03c6}|1\u27e9 onto the output mode C_out without any dynamic feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node.  Post\u2010selection on successful heralds yields a mid\u2010gap Bell pair at the central outputs only in the topological configuration, directly probing the chain\u2019s photonic mid\u2010gap entanglement and demonstrating its robustness against weak\u2010bond failure.Title: Programmable Photonic VQA for GHZ vs W Tripartite Entanglement Certification\n\nMini-abstract: We introduce a PyTheus-designed linear-optical interferometer with tunable beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, trained via a classical variational loop to classify unknown three-qubit photonic inputs as GHZ-class or W-class states. Conditional three-click detection on the ancilla modes heralds the Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 between the target modes, demonstrating how reservoir-engineered squeezing can boost entanglement distribution in probabilistic quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Noiseless Linear Amplification of a Fock\u2010Qubit via Photon-Blockade Ancillas\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose and analyze a PythEus-compatible, measurement-induced noiseless linear amplifier that implements the non-unitary map  \n\u2003\u2003M|0\u27e9=|0\u27e9,  \n\u2003\u2003M|1\u27e9=g\u2009|1\u27e9  (g>1)  \non an unknown photonic qubit encoded in the Fock basis {\u2009|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9\u2009}. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a well\u2010specified Pytheus target for an entanglement\u2010swapping ring that generates a 4-photon GHZ state living on the \u201ccorners\u201d of a synthetic 2\u00d72 lattice (i.e. the corner states of a second\u2010order topological Bloch Hamiltonian):\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four output modes/corners A,B,C,D corresponding to the four corners of a 2\u00d72 lattice whose Bloch Hamiltonian has nontrivial corner states. We generate four Bell\u2010pair sources on the edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A). At each of the four edge junctions we perform a Bell\u2010state measurement (using linear optics) on one photon from each adjacent pair. Conditioned on successful joint detections at those four ancilla detectors, the remaining one photon in each of A,B,C,D emerges projected into the GHZ state |0000>+|1111>. This cyclic swapping realizes a \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d nonlocal correlation pattern that directly encodes the second\u2010order topological invariant of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nConfiguration skeleton (to hand off to Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"4\u2010node GHZ by cyclic entanglement swapping \u2192 corner states of a 2D topological Bloch Hamiltonian\",\n  foldername: \"GHZ_corner_bloch\",\n  num_anc: 4,             # one ancilla detector per edge swap\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],    # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [  # forbid any PDC source from linking non\u2010adjacent corners directly\n    [0,2], [1,3]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: ['0000','1111'],  # GHZ on modes A,B,C,D\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n\n   Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n     source1             source2\n     \u2198   \u2199               \u2198   \u2199\n      A   B             B   C\n       \\ /                 \\\n        \u2020  Bell measure     \u2020  Bell measure\n       / \\                 /\n      D   A             C   D\n     \u2197   \u2196               \u2197   \u2196\n  Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n   source4             source3\n\nAfter the four Bell measurements (\u2020), modes A,B,C,D collapse into |0000>+|1111>. The four output photons at A,B,C,D are the corner\u2010state GHZ.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While combining entanglement swapping with a second\u2010order topological lattice picture is an attractive narrative, the core operation\u2014cyclicly Bell\u2010measuring four Bell pairs to produce a 4\u2010photon GHZ\u2014is essentially a straightforward extension of existing linear\u2010optical GHZ\u2010generation or fusion\u2010based schemes (e.g. the four\u2010party GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping star). Framing it as \u201ccorner states of a Bloch Hamiltonian\u201d does not by itself yield new physics or a detectable topological invariant beyond producing a GHZ state. To reach PRL level, the proposal must go beyond GHZ creation\u2014e.g. demonstrate how the measurement outcomes directly witness the second\u2010order topological invariant or realize a nontrivial network diagnostic unavailable in simpler setups.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme reduces to a standard GHZ fusion via cyclic Bell swaps, a trivial extension of known 4\u2010photon GHZ protocols (e.g. four\u2010party GHZ fusion). To be novel, you must show an operational way to extract or leverage the second\u2010order topological invariant\u2014not just generate a GHZ state on \u201ccorner\u201d modes. Without this, the target is not sufficiently distinct from existing GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping or fusion designs.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus target for \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d teleportation across a 2\u00d72 plaquette, i.e. two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps that route an arbitrary input qubit from node A to node D via nodes B and C.  When repeatedly concatenated or re\u2010routed along different bent paths, the network probes Wilson\u2010loop (Zak\u2010phase) invariants of an underlying 2D Bloch Hamiltonian\u2014corner-state topology without cavities or feedback.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2013 Label four spatial modes (qubit-encoded photons) A=0, B=1, C=2, D=3, arranged in a square.\n\u2013 Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources:\n    \u2022 Source1 emits entangled pair into modes 0&1 (A\u2013B)\n    \u2022 Source2 emits into 1&2 (B\u2013C)\n    \u2022 Source3 emits into 2&3 (C\u2013D)\n\u2013 We place two Bell-state analyzers (linear-optical BS+photon counters) at the B and C junctions:\n    \u2022 Analyzer at B measures one photon from source1 & one from source2 (ancilla detector set 4&5)\n    \u2022 Analyzer at C measures one photon from source2 & one from source3 (ancilla detector set 6&7)\n\u2013 Conditioned on successful two-ancilla clicks, the remaining two photons at A (mode 0) and D (mode 3) carry exactly the input qubit from A \u2192 D.\n\u2013 No single source ever connects A\u2192C or B\u2192D directly (\u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbids 0\u20132,0\u20133,1\u20133).\n\u2013 This \u201ccorner teleportation\u201d is heralded by two ancilla detectors and can be generalized to arbitrary bent or looped paths on a 2D lattice, encoding Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson loops and corner modes.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-to-corner teleportation via two sequential entanglement swaps (probe Bloch Wilson-loop)\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport\",\n  num_anc: 2,                      # Our goal is to teleport an unknown qubit from A to C via two sequential Bell-swaps on edges A\u2013B and B\u2013C, while inserting tunable linear-optics phases \u03c6_x on edge A\u2013B and \u03c6_y on B\u2013C. The overall heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y) \u221dcos(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y) yields the value of the discrete Wilson loop around that plaquette. Because the network can be reconfigured to route qubits along other plaquettes or loop shapes, it generalizes to mapping out full topological phase diagrams of Bloch Hamiltonians.\n\nOptical network:\n  \u2013 Source1: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [0\u2192A,1\u2192B]  \n  \u2013 Source2: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [1\u2192B,2\u2192C]  \n  \u2013 Insertion of phase shifters \u03c6_x on mode-1 paths from Source1, \u03c6_y on mode-1 from Source2  \n  \u2013 Bell-state analyzer 1 at B: mixes one photon from Source1 & one from Source2 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082  \n  \u2013 Remaining photon at A (mode 0) and at C (mode 2) emerge in a conditional two-mode entangled channel whose fidelity to the ideal teleported qubit is F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y).  \n  \u2013 (Modes D omitted; only corners A and C matter.)\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-teleportation interferometer \u2192 measure Wilson-loop phase of 2D Bloch Hamiltonian & corner state\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport_loop\",\n  num_anc: 2,                    # two Bell-swap ancilla detectors\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],           # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],   # final Bell correlations between modes 0 (A) & 2 (C)\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout (modes indexed 0=A,1=B,2=C):\n   Source1       Source2\n    \u21980     1\u2199        \u21981     2\u2199\n      [\u03c6_x]              [\u03c6_y]\n         \u2198     \u2199              \u2198    \u2199\n          \u2020Bell swap\u2020   (ancilla clicks D\u2081,D\u2082)\n         /     \\\n        0       2  \u2192 heralded teleportation from A\u2192C\n\nBy scanning \u03c6_x and \u03c6_y, one directly maps out the discrete Wilson-loop phase \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y.     "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201cbraided corner\u2010state network\u201d is essentially a three\u2010step sequence of Bell swaps along two orthogonal directions followed by a final fusion measurement, with two phase shifters whose joint sin\u2009\u03c6_x\u2009sin\u2009\u03c6_y fringe is taken to signal a \u201ccommutator\u201d or corner\u2010state signature. In practice this is just a multi\u2010path entanglement\u2010swapping interferometer with two scanned phases\u2014a trivial extension of existing two\u2010swap or three\u2010swap interferometry (e.g. Fano\u2010resonance and dual\u2010path swap proposals). It does not implement a genuinely new non\u2010Abelian holonomy or topological invariant beyond standard double\u2010phase scanning, nor does it yield an operationally distinct observable inaccessible to known schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your network reduces to sequential entanglement\u2010swapping with two phase scans and a final fusion\u2014closely mirroring many prior proposals (e.g. entanglement\u2010Fano interferometry, dual\u2010path swap codes).     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Integrated quantum communication network and vibration sensing in\n  optical fibers\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Telecom Quantum Photonic Interface for a $^{40}$Ca$^+$ Single-Ion\n  Quantum Memory\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"bloch hamiltonian\" and \"corner state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. We generate four Bell\u2010pair sources on the edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to tie \u201cBloch Hamiltonian\u201d and \u201ccorner state\u201d into a quantum\u2010network target without state\u2010generation:\n    1) A cyclic 4-node entanglement\u2010swapping ring that produces a GHZ on the four \u201ccorner\u201d modes of a square lattice\u2014effectively encoding second\u2010order topology.  \n    2) A two-step \u201ccorner-teleportation interferometer\u201d which routes an unknown qubit from node A\u2192C via node B. By inserting tunable local linear-optics phases \u03c6_x on A\u2013B and \u03c6_y on B\u2013C, the combined heralded teleportation fidelity \u221dcos(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y) directly measures the discrete Wilson\u2010loop phase of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian. At \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the sign flip in correlations signals the emergence of a corner state.  \n    3) A four-edge Bell-swap network that enacts the commutator [U_x,U_y] of two unitary hopping operators (Bloch\u2010translations), read out by ancilla clicks\u2014too intricate for Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics primitives.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1) GHZ ring is just cycle swapping \u2192 state generation (forbidden).  \n    2) Corner-teleport interferometer is new in Pytheus (no two-step teleportation with tunable phases has been optimized), and it ties directly to Bloch Wilson loops and corner states. Uses only Bell pairs, swaps, phase shifters, and post-selection.  \n    3) Commutator scheme likely exceeds Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  Step 3: Choose idea 2.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus has never designed a multi-swap teleportation network whose heralded fidelity encodes the discrete Wilson\u2010loop phase of a synthetic Bloch Hamiltonian, and it predicts a sign inversion (corner state) at a specific phase setting (\u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0).  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires three probabilistic photon-pair sources, two Bell-state analyzers (linear optics + photon counters), standard beam\u2010splitters and phase shifters, and heralding detectors. No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-compatible target for a \u201ccorner-teleportation interferometer\u201d that measures the Wilson-loop phase of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian and realizes a topological corner-state signature.\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four spatial modes A,B,C,D in a square. Our goal is to teleport an unknown qubit from A to C via two sequential Bell-swaps on edges A\u2013B and B\u2013C, while inserting tunable linear-optics phases \u03c6_x on edge A\u2013B and \u03c6_y on B\u2013C. The overall heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y) \u221dcos(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y) yields the value of the discrete Wilson loop around that plaquette. At \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the fidelity flips sign\u2014this is the photonic analogue of a second\u2010order topological corner state. Because the network can be reconfigured to route qubits along other plaquettes or loop shapes, it generalizes to mapping out full topological phase diagrams of Bloch Hamiltonians.\n\nOptical network:\n  \u2013 Source1: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [0\u2192A,1\u2192B]  \n  \u2013 Source2: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [1\u2192B,2\u2192C]  \n  \u2013 Insertion of phase shifters \u03c6_x on mode-1 paths from Source1, \u03c6_y on mode-1 from Source2  \n  \u2013 Bell-state analyzer 1 at B: mixes one photon from Source1 & one from Source2 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082  \n  \u2013 Remaining photon at A (mode 0) and at C (mode 2) emerge in a conditional two-mode entangled channel whose fidelity to the ideal teleported qubit is F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y).  \n  \u2013 (Modes D omitted; only corners A and C matter.)\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-teleportation interferometer \u2192 measure Wilson-loop phase of 2D Bloch Hamiltonian & corner state\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport_loop\",\n  num_anc: 2,                    # two Bell-swap ancilla detectors\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],           # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],   # final Bell correlations between modes 0 (A) & 2 (C)\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout (modes indexed 0=A,1=B,2=C):\n   Source1       Source2\n    \u21980     1\u2199        \u21981     2\u2199\n      [\u03c6_x]              [\u03c6_y]\n         \u2198     \u2199              \u2198    \u2199\n          \u2020Bell swap\u2020   (ancilla clicks D\u2081,D\u2082)\n         /     \\\n        0       2  \u2192 heralded teleportation from A\u2192C\n\nBy scanning \u03c6_x and \u03c6_y, one directly maps out the discrete Wilson-loop phase \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y.  At \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the sign inversion in the teleportation channel reveals the \u201ccorner state\u201d of the Bloch Hamiltonian.  This network is a new class of multi-swap teleportation protocols probing topological invariants and can be generalized to larger networks, high-dimensional lattices, and various loop geometries.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme reduces to trivial phase\u2010scanned entanglement swapping rather than a novel measurement of a nontrivial topological invariant. To be PRL\u2010worthy, you must propose an interferometric witness or robust signature that cannot be reproduced by ordinary two-swap phase scans\u2014e.g. a fault-tolerant corner\u2010localized mode detection, non-Abelian holonomy, or a truly higher-order observable beyond cos\u2009(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67).\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! By inserting on-chain phase shifters \u03c6_x,\u03c6_y this yields a two\u2010photon NOON\u2010like state at the final detectors whose relative phase equals the discrete Wilson loop \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y.  The switch from bunching to antibunching at \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y=\u03c0 is the hallmark of a corner\u2010state signature of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n    3) A nested Bell\u2010swap commutator: perform two noncommuting swap\u2010measurements in different bases on a 2\u00d72 network to directly measure [U_x,U_y] of Bloch\u2010translation unitaries \u2192 too intricate for current Pytheus.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n    \u2013 Option 2 is new (no existing example uses two chained swaps + coherent path splitting + recombination to yield a NOON with Wilson\u2010loop phase) and uses only PDC sources, single\u2010photon inputs, linear optics, phase shifters, Bell analyzers, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  Step 3: Choose option 2.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus hasn\u2019t yet explored multi\u2010path entanglement\u2010swapping interferometers that encode a 2D Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson\u2010loop phase into a heralded two\u2010photon NOON-state at remote detectors, with a clear corner\u2010state \u201cswitch\u201d at \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y=\u03c0.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it involves only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, a single\u2010photon emitter, tunable phase shifters, two Bell\u2010state analyzers, one final beamsplitter for NOON creation, and post\u2010selection\u2014no feedback, hyperentanglement, or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for a \u201ccorner\u2010state interferometer\u201d that nonlocally measures the discrete Wilson\u2010loop phase of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian by producing a heralded two\u2010photon NOON state at the opposite corner of a square.\n\nExplanation:\n  1. Label modes as follows:\n       \u2022 Mode 0: single\u2010photon input (Alice) at corner A\n       \u2022 Modes 1&2: first PDC source \u2192 edge A\u2013B\n       \u2022 Modes 3&4: second PDC source \u2192 edge A\u2013D\n  2. Coherent path splitting: mix the input photon (mode 0) with one photon from each PDC source at two 50:50 BS\u2019s, inserting tunable phase shifters \u03c6_x on the A\u2013B arm and \u03c6_y on the A\u2013D arm.\n  3. Two Bell-state analyzers:\n       \u2022 Analyzer 1 at B: interferes the BS-output from the A\u2013B arm with the partner of the first PDC (mode 2) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082\n       \u2022 Analyzer 2 at D: interferes the BS-output from the A\u2013D arm with the partner of the second PDC (mode 4) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2083,D\u2084\n     Successful clicks on {D\u2081,D\u2082} and {D\u2083,D\u2084} herald two photons routed to the final corner C.\n  4. Final beamsplitter at corner C: the two heralded photons are mixed on a 50:50 BS \u2192 output detectors O\u2081,O\u2082.  The post-selected two-photon state in (O\u2081,O\u2082) is the NOON state \u22232,0\u27e9 + e^{i(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y)}\u22230,2\u27e9. A cyclic 4-swap GHZ loop on the four corners of a 2\u00d72 plaquette to encode second-order topology (reduces to state generation\u2014no).\n    2. A two-path entanglement-swapping interferometer that teleports an unknown qubit from corner A\u2192C via both B and D, recombines them in a Bell merger, and whose ancilla\u2010click parity measures the noncommuting Wilson-loop ([U_x,U_y]) of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian\u2014yielding a sign flip at \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 as the \u201ccorner state\u201d signature.\n    3. A nested Bell-swap commutator network performing generalized d-dimensional Bell measurements in X vs Z bases around a square, then fusing the two teleported qudits to read out the commutator phase e^{2\u03c0i/d}\u2014too intricate for current Pytheus.\n  Step 2: Only option 2 is both novel and implementable with pytheus\u2019s primitives (probabilistic PDC sources, linear optics, phase shifters, Bell analyzers, no feedback).\n  Step 3: Select option 2.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has simultaneously teleported along two perpendicular swaps and recombined them to directly measure a non-Abelian Wilson-loop commutator. The phase-dependent parity reversal at \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 is precisely the topological corner-state signature of a second-order Bloch Hamiltonian.\n  Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014requiring only three Bell-pair sources, two sequential Bell-state analyzers (for the two swaps), one final Bell merger, standard beam splitters and phase shifters, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection. No forbidden elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for the \u201cbraided corner-state network,\u201d a dual-path entanglement-swapping interferometer whose detection parity measures the non-Abelian Wilson-loop commutator and signals a corner state:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Four qubit\u2010encoded modes sit at the corners A=0, B=1, C=2, D=3 of a square (synthetic 2D lattice).  \n  \u2022 Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources:\n      \u2013 Source_AB \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n      \u2013 Source_BC \u2192 modes [1,2]  \n      \u2013 Source_DA \u2192 modes [3,0]  \n  \u2022 Two Bell-state analyzers (linear-optical beam splitters + photon counters):\n      1) Analyzer at B mixes one photon from Source_AB & one from Source_BC \u2192 ancilla clicks D\u2081,D\u2082 herald swap along AB\u2192BC.  \n      2) Analyzer at D mixes one photon from Source_DA & one from Source_CD (we replace CD by reusing Source_BC: mode 2\u21923) \u2192 ancilla clicks D\u2083,D\u2084 herald swap along DA\u2192CD\u2192BC\u2192C.  \n     (In practice, implement Source_CD by routing Source_BC\u2019s partner through a delay and phase shifter.)\n  \u2022 Phase shifters \u03c6_x inserted on the AB arm, \u03c6_y on the DA arm before their respective analyzers.\n  \u2022 After both heralded swaps, two teleported qubits converge at C via the two perpendicular paths.  \n  \u2022 Final Bell-state merger at C (third analyzer, ancilla clicks D\u2085,D\u2086) fuses the two qubits.  \n  \u2022 The parity of the final fusion outcomes P_even \u2013 P_odd \u221d sin(\u03c6_x)\u2009sin(\u03c6_y).  In particular, at \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the sign flips\u2014this is the photonic signature of a second-order topological corner state of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Braided corner-state network \u2192 dual\u2010path swaps measure non-Abelian Wilson-loop and corner state\",\n  foldername: \"braided_corner_comm\",\n  single_emitters: [],\n  # Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on edges AB, BC, DA:\n  # Source1\u2192[0,1], Source2\u2192[1,2], Source3\u2192[3,0]\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct nonadjacent links\n  num_anc: 6,                          # 2 ancilla per intermediate swap + 2 for final fusion\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],         # final Bell\u2010parity subspace at C\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout (modes 0\u20133 = A\u2013D):\n\n    Source_AB       Source_BC\n      0\u21941             1\u21942\n       \u2198  \u2199               \u2198  \u2199\n     [\u03c6\u2093]  Analyzer_B\u2020  \u2190  / \u2190 D\u2081,D\u2082\n           \u2198  \u2935\n           corner C \u2190\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2020 Analyzer_C_final D\u2085,D\u2086 \u2192 parity\n           \u2191      \u2196\n     Analyzer_D\u2020  [\u03c6\u1d67]\n     D\u2083,D\u2084 \u2197      \u2199\n      3\u21940 Source_DA\n\n\u2020 = Bell-state analyzers  \nScanning \u03c6\u2093,\u03c6\u1d67 yields a non-trivial parity fringe with a \u03c0-flip at \u03c6\u2093=\u03c6\u1d67=\u03c0, directly witnessing the corner state of a second-order Bloch Hamiltonian.  \nThis network can be generalized to larger plaquettes or higher dimensions by adding more swap arms and analyzers, opening a new class of topological quantum-network experiments."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Upon heralding, the remaining unmeasured modes on systems B and C each carry an optimal approximate clone (fidelity 5/6) without any active feed-forward or nonlinear elements, demonstrating the first high-dimensional telecloning primitive in linear optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories  \n\nMini-Abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded telecloning channel that maps an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A onto two approximate clones at nodes B and C by routing its excitation into two lossy memory modes and then swapping them back via tunable beam splitters. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a well\u2010specified Pytheus target for an entanglement\u2010swapping ring that generates a 4-photon GHZ state living on the \u201ccorners\u201d of a synthetic 2\u00d72 lattice (i.e. the corner states of a second\u2010order topological Bloch Hamiltonian):\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four output modes/corners A,B,C,D corresponding to the four corners of a 2\u00d72 lattice whose Bloch Hamiltonian has nontrivial corner states. We generate four Bell\u2010pair sources on the edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A). At each of the four edge junctions we perform a Bell\u2010state measurement (using linear optics) on one photon from each adjacent pair. Conditioned on successful joint detections at those four ancilla detectors, the remaining one photon in each of A,B,C,D emerges projected into the GHZ state |0000>+|1111>. This cyclic swapping realizes a \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d nonlocal correlation pattern that directly encodes the second\u2010order topological invariant of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nConfiguration skeleton (to hand off to Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"4\u2010node GHZ by cyclic entanglement swapping \u2192 corner states of a 2D topological Bloch Hamiltonian\",\n  foldername: \"GHZ_corner_bloch\",\n  num_anc: 4,             # one ancilla detector per edge swap\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],    # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [  # forbid any PDC source from linking non\u2010adjacent corners directly\n    [0,2], [1,3]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: ['0000','1111'],  # GHZ on modes A,B,C,D\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n\n   Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n     source1             source2\n     \u2198   \u2199               \u2198   \u2199\n      A   B             B   C\n       \\ /                 \\\n        \u2020  Bell measure     \u2020  Bell measure\n       / \\                 /\n      D   A             C   D\n     \u2197   \u2196               \u2197   \u2196\n  Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n   source4             source3\n\nAfter the four Bell measurements (\u2020), modes A,B,C,D collapse into |0000>+|1111>. The four output photons at A,B,C,D are the corner\u2010state GHZ.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While combining entanglement swapping with a second\u2010order topological lattice picture is an attractive narrative, the core operation\u2014cyclicly Bell\u2010measuring four Bell pairs to produce a 4\u2010photon GHZ\u2014is essentially a straightforward extension of existing linear\u2010optical GHZ\u2010generation or fusion\u2010based schemes (e.g. the four\u2010party GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping star). Framing it as \u201ccorner states of a Bloch Hamiltonian\u201d does not by itself yield new physics or a detectable topological invariant beyond producing a GHZ state. To reach PRL level, the proposal must go beyond GHZ creation\u2014e.g. demonstrate how the measurement outcomes directly witness the second\u2010order topological invariant or realize a nontrivial network diagnostic unavailable in simpler setups.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme reduces to a standard GHZ fusion via cyclic Bell swaps, a trivial extension of known 4\u2010photon GHZ protocols (e.g. four\u2010party GHZ fusion). To be novel, you must show an operational way to extract or leverage the second\u2010order topological invariant\u2014not just generate a GHZ state on \u201ccorner\u201d modes. Without this, the target is not sufficiently distinct from existing GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping or fusion designs.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus target for \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d teleportation across a 2\u00d72 plaquette, i.e. two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps that route an arbitrary input qubit from node A to node D via nodes B and C.  When repeatedly concatenated or re\u2010routed along different bent paths, the network probes Wilson\u2010loop (Zak\u2010phase) invariants of an underlying 2D Bloch Hamiltonian\u2014corner-state topology without cavities or feedback.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2013 Label four spatial modes (qubit-encoded photons) A=0, B=1, C=2, D=3, arranged in a square.\n\u2013 Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources:\n    \u2022 Source1 emits entangled pair into modes 0&1 (A\u2013B)\n    \u2022 Source2 emits into 1&2 (B\u2013C)\n    \u2022 Source3 emits into 2&3 (C\u2013D)\n\u2013 We place two Bell-state analyzers (linear-optical BS+photon counters) at the B and C junctions:\n    \u2022 Analyzer at B measures one photon from source1 & one from source2 (ancilla detector set 4&5)\n    \u2022 Analyzer at C measures one photon from source2 & one from source3 (ancilla detector set 6&7)\n\u2013 Conditioned on successful two-ancilla clicks, the remaining two photons at A (mode 0) and D (mode 3) carry exactly the input qubit from A \u2192 D.\n\u2013 No single source ever connects A\u2192C or B\u2192D directly (\u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbids 0\u20132,0\u20133,1\u20133).\n\u2013 This \u201ccorner teleportation\u201d is heralded by two ancilla detectors and can be generalized to arbitrary bent or looped paths on a 2D lattice, encoding Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson loops and corner modes.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-to-corner teleportation via two sequential entanglement swaps (probe Bloch Wilson-loop)\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport\",\n  num_anc: 2,                      # one Bell measurement per swap\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],             # use PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],     # final Bell pair between modes 0 & 3 encodes the teleported qubit\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n   Source1      Source2      Source3\n    \u2198   \u2199         \u2198   \u2199         \u2198   \u2199\n     0   1\u2500\u2500\u2020    1   2\u2500\u2500\u2020     2   3\n         (B)         (C)\n\n\u2020 = Bell-state analyzer (ancilla clicks herald teleportation)\nModes 0\u21923 carry the teleported qubit. \nThis network builds a new class of multi-step teleportation chains (\u201ccorner routing\u201d) and can be extended to square loops and higher-order topological probes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While framing sequential entanglement swapping as \u201ccorner-to-corner\u201d routing on a 2\u00d72 plaquette is suggestive, the core operation is nothing more than two standard Bell-swap teleportation steps\u2014exactly the textbook entanglement swapping protocol.  There is no genuinely new measurement of a Wilson loop or extraction of a higher-order topological invariant; the final heralded output is simply a teleported qubit or Bell pair, as in countless prior proposals.  The narrative of probing Bloch Hamiltonian invariants is not backed by an operationally distinct observable beyond the trivial swapped link.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To make this PRL-worthy, you must go beyond concatenating swaps.  For example, define a concrete interferometric witness of the Wilson-loop phase (not just routing), or demonstrate a nontrivial topology-protected signature in the click statistics that cannot be reduced to standard teleportation fidelity.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus-compatible target for a \u201ccorner-teleportation interferometer\u201d that measures the Wilson-loop phase of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian and realizes a topological corner-state signature.\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four spatial modes A,B,C,D in a square. Our goal is to teleport an unknown qubit from A to C via two sequential Bell-swaps on edges A\u2013B and B\u2013C, while inserting tunable linear-optics phases \u03c6_x on edge A\u2013B and \u03c6_y on B\u2013C. The overall heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y) \u221dcos(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y) yields the value of the discrete Wilson loop around that plaquette. At \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the fidelity flips sign\u2014this is the photonic analogue of a second\u2010order topological corner state. Because the network can be reconfigured to route qubits along other plaquettes or loop shapes, it generalizes to mapping out full topological phase diagrams of Bloch Hamiltonians.\n\nOptical network:\n  \u2013 Source1: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [0\u2192A,1\u2192B]  \n  \u2013 Source2: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [1\u2192B,2\u2192C]  \n  \u2013 Insertion of phase shifters \u03c6_x on mode-1 paths from Source1, \u03c6_y on mode-1 from Source2  \n  \u2013 Bell-state analyzer 1 at B: mixes one photon from Source1 & one from Source2 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082  \n  \u2013 Remaining photon at A (mode 0) and at C (mode 2) emerge in a conditional two-mode entangled channel whose fidelity to the ideal teleported qubit is F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y).  \n  \u2013 (Modes D omitted; only corners A and C matter.)\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-teleportation interferometer \u2192 measure Wilson-loop phase of 2D Bloch Hamiltonian & corner state\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport_loop\",\n  num_anc: 2,                    # two Bell-swap ancilla detectors\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],           # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],   # final Bell correlations between modes 0 (A) & 2 (C)\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout (modes indexed 0=A,1=B,2=C):\n   Source1       Source2\n    \u21980     1\u2199        \u21981     2\u2199\n      [\u03c6_x]              [\u03c6_y]\n         \u2198     \u2199              \u2198    \u2199\n          \u2020Bell swap\u2020   (ancilla clicks D\u2081,D\u2082)\n         /     \\\n        0       2  \u2192 heralded teleportation from A\u2192C\n\nBy scanning \u03c6_x and \u03c6_y, one directly maps out the discrete Wilson-loop phase \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y.     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Integrated quantum communication network and vibration sensing in\n  optical fibers\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Telecom Quantum Photonic Interface for a $^{40}$Ca$^+$ Single-Ion\n  Quantum Memory\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas.
