Modes:\n   \u2022 A=0, B=1, C=2, D=3 are the four corners of a square.  \n   \u2022 R=4 is an external reference qubit.  \n2. Photon\u2010pair sources:\n   \u2022 Source_REF \u2192 modes [4,0] creates a reference Bell pair R\u2013A.  \n   \u2022 Source_AB \u2192 [0,1] (edge A\u2013B)  \n   \u2022 Source_BC \u2192 [1,2] (B\u2013C)  \n   \u2022 Source_CD \u2192 [2,3] (C\u2013D)  \n   \u2022 Source_DA \u2192 [3,0] (D\u2013A)  \n3. Alternating reflectivities:\n   \u2022 Beam splitters on edges AB & CD have reflectivity r\u2081 (\u201cintra\u2010cell\u201d coupling).  \n   \u2022 Beam splitters on edges BC & DA have reflectivity r\u2082 (\u201cinter\u2010cell\u201d coupling).  \n   Tuning r\u2081,r\u2082 simulates the BBH quadrupole model\u2019s alternating hoppings.  \n4. Four sequential Bell\u2010swap analyzers:\n   \u2013 Analyzer_AB mixes modes (0,1) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald swap along AB.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_BC mixes (1,2) \u2192 D\u2083,D\u2084 herald BC.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_CD mixes (2,3) \u2192 D\u2085,D\u2086 herald CD.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_DA mixes (3,0) \u2192 D\u2087,D\u2088 herald DA.  \n   Each analyzer is a 50:50 BS with adjustable r (the same BS that implements swapping) and two photon\u2010counters.  \n5. After four successful ancilla clicks, the reference qubit at R and the teleported qubit return to mode A if the network is in the trivial phase (r\u2081>r\u2082), or remain localized at D and B if in the topological phase (r\u2081<r\u2082)\u2014corner\u2010state localization of entanglement.  \n6. Final parity readout:\n   \u2013 We perform a Bell\u2010parity analyzer on modes [4,0] (R\u2013A) and another on [4,2] (R\u2013C) in separate runs.  \n   \u2013 In the trivial regime one finds high R\u2013A fidelity; in the topological regime (r\u2081<r\u2082) R\u2013A fidelity collapses and R\u2013C (or R\u2013D) fidelity peaks\u2014directly witnessing the emergence of a corner state.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement\u2010pumping corner\u2010state network \u2192 simulate BBH quadrupole model via alternating BS reflectivities & detect corner\u2010state localization\",\n  foldername: \"ent_pump_corner\",\n  single_emitters: [],\n\n  # Photon\u2010pair sources:\n  #   REF\u2192[4,0], AB\u2192[0,1], BC\u2192[1,2], CD\u2192[2,3], DA\u2192[3,0]\n  removed_connections: [[4,1],[4,2],[4,3]],\n\n  # Four Bell analyzers (one per edge):\n  num_anc: 8,    \n  num_pre: 1,\n\n  # Beam-splitter reflectivities as tunable parameters:\n  reflectivities: ['r1 on AB & CD','r2 on BC & DA'],\n\n  # Final Bell-parity readout settings (modes [4,0] vs [4,2] in different runs):\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],\n\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n\n   Source_REF      Source_AB(r\u2081)    Source_BC(r\u2082)    Source_CD(r\u2081)    Source_DA(r\u2082)\n     4\u21940             0\u21941              1\u21942              2\u21943              3\u21940\n        \u2198            \u2199 Swap_AB\u2020       \u2199 Swap_BC\u2020       \u2199 Swap_CD\u2020       \u2199 Swap_DA\u2020\n        (Bell analyzers D\u2081\u2013D\u2088 implement sequential swaps with reflectivities r\u2081,r\u2082)\n             \u2198   \u2199                     \u2198   \u2199\n           mode 0 returns or relocates to modes 2/3 (corner localization)\n             \u2198   \u2199\n      Final Bell\u2010parity analyzers at [4,0] & [4,2]\n\nCorner\u2010state signature:\n\u2013 Varying (r\u2081,r\u2082) across the BBH phase diagram, entanglement \u201cpumps\u201d from A to opposite corners.  \n\u2013 In the topological phase (r\u2081<r\u2082), the four\u2010swap loop localizes the reference entanglement at the diagonal corner\u2014observed as a collapse of R\u2013A fidelity and a peak in R\u2013C (or R\u2013D) parity.  \n\u2013 This network-level entanglement pumping and corner\u2010state localization can be generalized to larger lattices, higher\u2010order loops, and multi\u2010parameter topological mappings\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, static\u2010reflectivity, and post\u2010selection toolkit."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Three-Mode Imaginary\u2010Time Filtering for GHZ\u2083 Entanglement Swapping\n\nAbstract: We present a photonic protocol that embeds the genuinely nonunitary three\u2010mode imaginary\u2010time evolution operator K\u221dexp[\u2013\u03b2(\u03c3\u2093\u2297\u03c3\u1d67\u2297\u03c3_z)] for the target Hamiltonian H\u2083 directly into a three\u2010party GHZ entanglement swap at the relay node. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a well\u2010specified Pytheus target for an entanglement\u2010swapping ring that generates a 4-photon GHZ state living on the \u201ccorners\u201d of a synthetic 2\u00d72 lattice (i.e. the corner states of a second\u2010order topological Bloch Hamiltonian):\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four output modes/corners A,B,C,D corresponding to the four corners of a 2\u00d72 lattice whose Bloch Hamiltonian has nontrivial corner states. We generate four Bell\u2010pair sources on the edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A). At each of the four edge junctions we perform a Bell\u2010state measurement (using linear optics) on one photon from each adjacent pair. Conditioned on successful joint detections at those four ancilla detectors, the remaining one photon in each of A,B,C,D emerges projected into the GHZ state |0000>+|1111>. This cyclic swapping realizes a \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d nonlocal correlation pattern that directly encodes the second\u2010order topological invariant of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nConfiguration skeleton (to hand off to Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"4\u2010node GHZ by cyclic entanglement swapping \u2192 corner states of a 2D topological Bloch Hamiltonian\",\n  foldername: \"GHZ_corner_bloch\",\n  num_anc: 4,             # one ancilla detector per edge swap\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],    # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [  # forbid any PDC source from linking non\u2010adjacent corners directly\n    [0,2], [1,3]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: ['0000','1111'],  # GHZ on modes A,B,C,D\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n\n   Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n     source1             source2\n     \u2198   \u2199               \u2198   \u2199\n      A   B             B   C\n       \\ /                 \\\n        \u2020  Bell measure     \u2020  Bell measure\n       / \\                 /\n      D   A             C   D\n     \u2197   \u2196               \u2197   \u2196\n  Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n   source4             source3\n\nAfter the four Bell measurements (\u2020), modes A,B,C,D collapse into |0000>+|1111>. The four output photons at A,B,C,D are the corner\u2010state GHZ.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While combining entanglement swapping with a second\u2010order topological lattice picture is an attractive narrative, the core operation\u2014cyclicly Bell\u2010measuring four Bell pairs to produce a 4\u2010photon GHZ\u2014is essentially a straightforward extension of existing linear\u2010optical GHZ\u2010generation or fusion\u2010based schemes (e.g. the four\u2010party GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping star). Framing it as \u201ccorner states of a Bloch Hamiltonian\u201d does not by itself yield new physics or a detectable topological invariant beyond producing a GHZ state. To reach PRL level, the proposal must go beyond GHZ creation\u2014e.g. demonstrate how the measurement outcomes directly witness the second\u2010order topological invariant or realize a nontrivial network diagnostic unavailable in simpler setups.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme reduces to a standard GHZ fusion via cyclic Bell swaps, a trivial extension of known 4\u2010photon GHZ protocols (e.g. four\u2010party GHZ fusion). To be novel, you must show an operational way to extract or leverage the second\u2010order topological invariant\u2014not just generate a GHZ state on \u201ccorner\u201d modes. Without this, the target is not sufficiently distinct from existing GHZ entanglement\u2010swapping or fusion designs.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus target for \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d teleportation across a 2\u00d72 plaquette, i.e. two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps that route an arbitrary input qubit from node A to node D via nodes B and C.  When repeatedly concatenated or re\u2010routed along different bent paths, the network probes Wilson\u2010loop (Zak\u2010phase) invariants of an underlying 2D Bloch Hamiltonian\u2014corner-state topology without cavities or feedback.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2013 Label four spatial modes (qubit-encoded photons) A=0, B=1, C=2, D=3, arranged in a square.\n\u2013 Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources:\n    \u2022 Source1 emits entangled pair into modes 0&1 (A\u2013B)\n    \u2022 Source2 emits into 1&2 (B\u2013C)\n    \u2022 Source3 emits into 2&3 (C\u2013D)\n\u2013 We place two Bell-state analyzers (linear-optical BS+photon counters) at the B and C junctions:\n    \u2022 Analyzer at B measures one photon from source1 & one from source2 (ancilla detector set 4&5)\n    \u2022 Analyzer at C measures one photon from source2 & one from source3 (ancilla detector set 6&7)\n\u2013 Conditioned on successful two-ancilla clicks, the remaining two photons at A (mode 0) and D (mode 3) carry exactly the input qubit from A \u2192 D.\n\u2013 No single source ever connects A\u2192C or B\u2192D directly (\u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbids 0\u20132,0\u20133,1\u20133).\n\u2013 This \u201ccorner teleportation\u201d is heralded by two ancilla detectors and can be generalized to arbitrary bent or looped paths on a 2D lattice, encoding Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson loops and corner modes.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-to-corner teleportation via two sequential entanglement swaps (probe Bloch Wilson-loop)\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport\",\n  num_anc: 2,                      # There is no genuinely new measurement of a Wilson loop or extraction of a higher-order topological invariant; the final heralded output is simply a teleported qubit or Bell pair, as in countless prior proposals.  The narrative of probing Bloch Hamiltonian invariants is not backed by an operationally distinct observable beyond the trivial swapped link.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To make this PRL-worthy, you must go beyond concatenating swaps.  For example, define a concrete interferometric witness of the Wilson-loop phase (not just routing), or demonstrate a nontrivial topology-protected signature in the click statistics that cannot be reduced to standard teleportation fidelity.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus-compatible target for a \u201ccorner-teleportation interferometer\u201d that measures the Wilson-loop phase of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian and realizes a topological corner-state signature.\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four spatial modes A,B,C,D in a square. Our goal is to teleport an unknown qubit from A to C via two sequential Bell-swaps on edges A\u2013B and B\u2013C, while inserting tunable linear-optics phases \u03c6_x on edge A\u2013B and \u03c6_y on B\u2013C. The overall heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y) \u221dcos(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y) yields the value of the discrete Wilson loop around that plaquette. At \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the fidelity flips sign\u2014this is the photonic analogue of a second\u2010order topological corner state. Because the network can be reconfigured to route qubits along other plaquettes or loop shapes, it generalizes to mapping out full topological phase diagrams of Bloch Hamiltonians.\n\nOptical network:\n  \u2013 Source1: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [0\u2192A,1\u2192B]  \n  \u2013 Source2: probabilistic Bell pair into modes [1\u2192B,2\u2192C]  \n  \u2013 Insertion of phase shifters \u03c6_x on mode-1 paths from Source1, \u03c6_y on mode-1 from Source2  \n  \u2013 Bell-state analyzer 1 at B: mixes one photon from Source1 & one from Source2 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082  \n  \u2013 Remaining photon at A (mode 0) and at C (mode 2) emerge in a conditional two-mode entangled channel whose fidelity to the ideal teleported qubit is F(\u03c6_x,\u03c6_y).  \n  \u2013 (Modes D omitted; only corners A and C matter.)\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Corner-teleportation interferometer \u2192 measure Wilson-loop phase of 2D Bloch Hamiltonian & corner state\",\n  foldername: \"corner_teleport_loop\",\n  num_anc: 2,                    # two Bell-swap ancilla detectors\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],           # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[2,3]],\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],   # final Bell correlations between modes 0 (A) & 2 (C)\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout (modes indexed 0=A,1=B,2=C):\n   Source1       Source2\n    \u21980     1\u2199        \u21981     2\u2199\n      [\u03c6_x]              [\u03c6_y]\n         \u2198     \u2199              \u2198    \u2199\n          \u2020Bell swap\u2020   (ancilla clicks D\u2081,D\u2082)\n         /     \\\n        0       2  \u2192 heralded teleportation from A\u2192C\n\nBy scanning \u03c6_x and \u03c6_y, one directly maps out the discrete Wilson-loop phase \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y.  At \u03c6_x=\u03c6_y=\u03c0 the sign inversion in the teleportation channel reveals the \u201ccorner state\u201d of the Bloch Hamiltonian.  This network is a new class of multi-swap teleportation protocols probing topological invariants and can be generalized to larger networks, high-dimensional lattices, and various loop geometries.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal remains a two\u2010step Bell\u2010swap teleportation decorated with tunable phase shifters \u03c6\u2093,\u03c6\u1d67 whose only signature is a cos(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67) fringe in the teleportation fidelity. It adds no genuinely new operational probe of a 2D Wilson loop or second\u2010order topology beyond standard interferometric phase sensing in entanglement swapping. In particular, the core is identical to textbook sequential teleportation or the ensemble\u2019s \u201cflux\u2010controlled chiral teleportation\u201d and \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner SSH teleportation\u201d schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme reduces to trivial phase\u2010scanned entanglement swapping rather than a novel measurement of a nontrivial topological invariant. Label modes as follows:\n       \u2022 Mode 0: single\u2010photon input (Alice) at corner A\n       \u2022 Modes 1&2: first PDC source \u2192 edge A\u2013B\n       \u2022 Modes 3&4: second PDC source \u2192 edge A\u2013D\n  2. Coherent path splitting: mix the input photon (mode 0) with one photon from each PDC source at two 50:50 BS\u2019s, inserting tunable phase shifters \u03c6_x on the A\u2013B arm and \u03c6_y on the A\u2013D arm.\n  3. Two Bell-state analyzers:\n       \u2022 Analyzer 1 at B: interferes the BS-output from the A\u2013B arm with the partner of the first PDC (mode 2) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082\n       \u2022 Analyzer 2 at D: interferes the BS-output from the A\u2013D arm with the partner of the second PDC (mode 4) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2083,D\u2084\n     Successful clicks on {D\u2081,D\u2082} and {D\u2083,D\u2084} herald two photons routed to the final corner C.\n  4. Final beamsplitter at corner C: the two heralded photons are mixed on a 50:50 BS \u2192 output detectors O\u2081,O\u2082.  The post-selected two-photon state in (O\u2081,O\u2082) is the NOON state \u22232,0\u27e9 + e^{i(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y)}\u22230,2\u27e9.  Scanning \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y from 0\u21922\u03c0 produces a HOM-like interference fringe. Each successful analyzer click (4 ancilla detectors total) heralds one link swap.  \n5) Conditioned on all four ancilla clicks, the remaining photon at mode 0 (A) and the reference at mode 4 (R) emerge. In the topological quadrupole phase (\u03c6\u2093=\u03c6_y=\u03c0), the protocol picks up a \u03c0 Berry phase around the loop, flipping the parity of the R\u2013A Bell outcome\u2014this sign flip is the hallmark of a corner state.  \n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Looped-teleportation corner-state witness \u2192 simulate quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian & detect corner state via entanglement fidelity\",\n  foldername: \"quad_loop_corner_witness\",\n  single_emitters: [],        # Input splitting: a 50:50 BS (BS_in) mixes the input at mode 0 with vacuum \u2192 branches modes 0 (to AB\u2010swap circuit) and 5 (to AD\u2010swap circuit).  \n2. Phase imprint: static phase \u03c6\u2093 on the AB branch, \u03c6\u1d67 on the AD branch.  \n3. Bell\u2010state analyzer at B: a 50:50 BS mixes mode 0 (post\u2010\u03c6\u2093) with PDC1 mode 1 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald A\u2192B swap.  \n4. Output recombination: a final 50:50 BS (BS_out) mixes modes [2,4] \u2192 detectors O\u2081,O\u2082.  \n7. Post\u2010select on clicks (D\u2081..D\u2084 and exactly one click at O\u2081 or O\u2082). Photon\u2010pair sources:\n   \u2022 Source_REF \u2192 modes [4,0] creates a reference Bell pair R\u2013A.  \n   \u2022 Source_AB \u2192 [0,1] (edge A\u2013B)  \n   \u2022 Source_BC \u2192 [1,2] (B\u2013C)  \n   \u2022 Source_CD \u2192 [2,3] (C\u2013D)  \n   \u2022 Source_DA \u2192 [3,0] (D\u2013A)  \n3. Alternating reflectivities:\n   \u2022 Beam splitters on edges AB & CD have reflectivity r\u2081 (\u201cintra\u2010cell\u201d coupling).  \n   \u2022 Beam splitters on edges BC & DA have reflectivity r\u2082 (\u201cinter\u2010cell\u201d coupling).  \n   Tuning r\u2081,r\u2082 simulates the BBH quadrupole model\u2019s alternating hoppings.  \n4. Four sequential Bell\u2010swap analyzers:\n   \u2013 Analyzer_AB mixes modes (0,1) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald swap along AB.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_BC mixes (1,2) \u2192 D\u2083,D\u2084 herald BC.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_CD mixes (2,3) \u2192 D\u2085,D\u2086 herald CD.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_DA mixes (3,0) \u2192 D\u2087,D\u2088 herald DA.  \n   Each analyzer is a 50:50 BS with adjustable r (the same BS that implements swapping) and two photon\u2010counters.  \n5. After four successful ancilla clicks, the reference qubit at R and the teleported qubit return to mode A if the network is in the trivial phase (r\u2081>r\u2082), or remain localized at D and B if in the topological phase (r\u2081<r\u2082)\u2014corner\u2010state localization of entanglement.  \n6. Final parity readout:\n   \u2013 We perform a Bell\u2010parity analyzer on modes [4,0] (R\u2013A) and another on [4,2] (R\u2013C) in separate runs.  \n   \u2013 In the trivial regime one finds high R\u2013A fidelity; in the topological regime (r\u2081<r\u2082) R\u2013A fidelity collapses and R\u2013C (or R\u2013D) fidelity peaks\u2014directly witnessing the emergence of a corner state.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement\u2010pumping corner\u2010state network \u2192 simulate BBH quadrupole model via alternating BS reflectivities & detect corner\u2010state localization\",\n  foldername: \"ent_pump_corner\",\n  single_emitters: [],\n\n  #     "output": "Thought: This \u201centanglement-pumping corner-state network\u201d again reduces to a 2\u00d72 loop of four sequential Bell-swap operations with tunable beam-splitter reflectivities (r\u2081,r\u2082) \u2013 exactly the same network structure as earlier \u201clooped-teleportation\u201d and \u201cZak-phase tomography\u201d schemes, merely replacing phase shifts with reflectivity control. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"bloch hamiltonian\" and \"corner state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The switch from bunching to antibunching at \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y=\u03c0 is the hallmark of a corner\u2010state signature of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n    3) A nested Bell\u2010swap commutator: perform two noncommuting swap\u2010measurements in different bases on a 2\u00d72 network to directly measure [U_x,U_y] of Bloch\u2010translation unitaries \u2192 too intricate for current Pytheus.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n    \u2013 Option 2 is new (no existing example uses two chained swaps + coherent path splitting + recombination to yield a NOON with Wilson\u2010loop phase) and uses only PDC sources, single\u2010photon inputs, linear optics, phase shifters, Bell analyzers, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  Step 3: Choose option 2.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus hasn\u2019t yet explored multi\u2010path entanglement\u2010swapping interferometers that encode a 2D Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson\u2010loop phase into a heralded two\u2010photon NOON-state at remote detectors, with a clear corner\u2010state \u201cswitch\u201d at \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y=\u03c0.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it involves only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, a single\u2010photon emitter, tunable phase shifters, two Bell\u2010state analyzers, one final beamsplitter for NOON creation, and post\u2010selection\u2014no feedback, hyperentanglement, or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for a \u201ccorner\u2010state interferometer\u201d that nonlocally measures the discrete Wilson\u2010loop phase of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian by producing a heralded two\u2010photon NOON state at the opposite corner of a square.\n\nExplanation:\n  1. Label modes as follows:\n       \u2022 Mode 0: single\u2010photon input (Alice) at corner A\n       \u2022 Modes 1&2: first PDC source \u2192 edge A\u2013B\n       \u2022 Modes 3&4: second PDC source \u2192 edge A\u2013D\n  2. Two Bell-state analyzers:\n       \u2022 Analyzer 1 at B: interferes the BS-output from the A\u2013B arm with the partner of the first PDC (mode 2) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082\n       \u2022 Analyzer 2 at D: interferes the BS-output from the A\u2013D arm with the partner of the second PDC (mode 4) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2083,D\u2084\n     Successful clicks on {D\u2081,D\u2082} and {D\u2083,D\u2084} herald two photons routed to the final corner C.\n  4. Final beamsplitter at corner C: the two heralded photons are mixed on a 50:50 BS \u2192 output detectors O\u2081,O\u2082.  The post-selected two-photon state in (O\u2081,O\u2082) is the NOON state \u22232,0\u27e9 + e^{i(\u03c6_x+\u03c6_y)}\u22230,2\u27e9.  Scanning \u03c6_x+\u03c6_y from 0\u21922\u03c0 produces a HOM-like interference fringe. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to tie \u201cBloch Hamiltonian\u201d and \u201ccorner state\u201d into a quantum-network (no forbidden state generation):\n    1) A cyclic 4-swap \u201cGHZ ring\u201d on the corners of a 2\u00d72 plaquette to encode second-order topology \u2192 reduces to state generation (forbidden).\n    2) A two-path entanglement-swapping interferometer around the square (A\u2192B\u2192C vs A\u2192D\u2192C) whose interference parity at C measures the Wilson-loop phase \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67, with a \u03c0-jump at (\u03c0,\u03c0) marking a corner state \u2192 essentially a NOON interferometer (too close to existing schemes).\n    3) A single-route \u201clooped teleportation\u201d of an unknown qubit A\u2192A around the 2\u00d72 plaquette via four sequential Bell-swaps, starting from an entangled pair (R\u2013A) and ending by re-fusing at A to test how well R\u2013A remains entangled. By tuning the beam-splitter \u201chopping\u201d phases on alternating edges (simulating the BBH quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian), the teleportation fidelity F(\u03c6\u2093,\u03c6\u1d67) exhibits a sharp dip or sign change exactly when the model hosts a corner state.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    \u2013 Option 1 is out. Option 2 is interesting but too similar to two-swap phase interferometers. Option 3 is novel: it uses a closed-loop teleportation channel to simulate a Floquet step of the quadrupole model and then reads out a corner-state signature via entanglement fidelity.  \n    \u2013 Feasible with Pytheus: needs one reference Bell source, four link Bell sources, four sequential Bell analyzers, linear optics, phases, and post-selection. No feedback, no cavities.  \n  Step 3: Pick option 3.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has used a closed-loop entanglement-swap teleportation channel to simulate a 2D quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian and to read out its corner-state by measuring the survival of a reference entangled pair.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints: only probabilistic pair sources, linear-optical Bell measurements, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-compatible target for a \u201clooped teleportation corner-state witness\u201d that simulates the BBH quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian around a 2\u00d72 plaquette and reads out the topological corner state via entanglement-swap fidelity:\n\nExplanation:\n1) We label four \u201clattice\u201d corners A=0, B=1, C=2, D=3 and an external reference qubit R=4.  \n2) We start with a reference Bell pair (R\u2013A) created by Source_REF \u2192 modes [4,0].  \n3) Four additional probabilistic Bell sources implement the plaquette edges:\n     \u2022 Source_AB \u2192 [0,1] (hopping t\u2081)\n     \u2022 Source_BC \u2192 [1,2] (t\u2082)\n     \u2022 Source_CD \u2192 [2,3] (t\u2081)\n     \u2022 Source_DA \u2192 [3,0] (t\u2082)  \n   We insert tunable phase shifters \u03c6\u2093 on edges AB and CD, and \u03c6_y on edges BC and DA to simulate the alternating intra\u2010/inter\u2010cell hoppings of the BBH model.  \n4) We perform four sequential Bell\u2010state measurements (linear-optical analyzers + photon counters) along the loop A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192D, D\u2192A\u2014and finally re-teleport the qubit back to mode 0. Each successful analyzer click (4 ancilla detectors total) heralds one link swap.  \n5) Conditioned on all four ancilla clicks, the remaining photon at mode 0 (A) and the reference at mode 4 (R) emerge. We then check their entanglement via parity detection (Bell basis) as our final \u201ccorner\u2010state witness.\u201d  \n6) In the trivial Bloch phase (\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6_y=0), the closed-loop teleportation faithfully preserves the R\u2013A Bell correlations. In the topological quadrupole phase (\u03c6\u2093=\u03c6_y=\u03c0), the protocol picks up a \u03c0 Berry phase around the loop, flipping the parity of the R\u2013A Bell outcome\u2014this sign flip is the hallmark of a corner state.  \n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Looped-teleportation corner-state witness \u2192 simulate quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian & detect corner state via entanglement fidelity\",\n  foldername: \"quad_loop_corner_witness\",\n  single_emitters: [],        # all sources are probabilistic PDC\n  # Bell-pair sources:\n  #   REF\u2192[4,0], AB\u2192[0,1], BC\u2192[1,2], CD\u2192[2,3], DA\u2192[3,0]\n  removed_connections: [[4,1],[4,2],[4,3]],  # forbid direct reference links\n  num_anc: 4,                 # one Bell measurement per edge\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],# R\u2013A Bell parity at the end\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout (modes 0\u20133 = A\u2013D, mode 4 = R):\n      Source_REF       Source_AB      Source_BC      Source_CD      Source_DA\n        4\u21940             0\u21941            1\u21942            2\u21943            3\u21940\n           \u2198             \u2199 Bell          \u2199 Bell         \u2199 Bell       \u2199 Bell\n       [R\u2013A]        Analyzer1       Analyzer2       Analyzer3    Analyzer4\n           \u2196             \u2198            \u2198            \u2198           \u2198\n                             Final R\u2013A Bell measurement\n\nBy scanning the phases \u03c6\u2093,\u03c6_y on alternating edges, one simulates the BBH quadrupole Hamiltonian and directly reads out its corner state via the parity flip of the surviving R\u2013A entanglement.  \nGeneralizations: larger plaquettes, higher dimensions, multi-loop braids, and network-encoded higher-order invariants.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The target reduces to standard sequential Bell swaps with phase scans\u2014closely mirroring prior \u201cZak Phase Tomography\u201d and looped teleportation schemes. By inserting alternating phase\u2010shifters \u03c6\u2093 on edges AB & CD and \u03c6\u1d67 on edges BC & DA, this simulates one Floquet step of the BBH quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian.  At the end we re\u2010fuse the teleported qubit with the reference at A and measure their Bell\u2010parity. Input splitting: a 50:50 BS (BS_in) mixes the input at mode 0 with vacuum \u2192 branches modes 0 (to AB\u2010swap circuit) and 5 (to AD\u2010swap circuit).  \n2. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: We want a truly novel Pytheus\u2010compatible network\u2014one that isn\u2019t just another state\u2010generation or simple two\u2010swap protocol, but actually uses entanglement\u2010swap interference around a synthetic 2\u00d72 Bloch lattice to witness second\u2010order corner topology. The idea is a \u201ctopological entanglement\u2010witness network\u201d where two parallel swap paths around the square (via B and via D) coherently combine at the diagonal corners. Conditioning on ancilla clicks at B and D, the resulting diagonal Bell pair \u222300\u27e9+e^{i(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67)}\u222311\u27e9 appears only when the sum of the two link phases \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67=\u03c0\u2014exactly the corner\u2010state signature of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian\u2019s Wilson\u2010loop. This uses only four probabilistic pair sources on edges, two linear\u2010optical Bell analyzers (no feedback), static phase shifters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014a perfect fit for Pytheus.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\n{\n  description: \"Topological entanglement\u2010witness network: heralded diagonal Bell pair only in corner\u2010state regime\",\n  foldername: \"topo_ent_witness\",\n  single_emitters: [],\n\n  # Four probabilistic photon-pair sources on edges of a square:\n  #   AB\u2192[0,1], BC\u2192[1,2], CD\u2192[2,3], DA\u2192[3,0]\n  # Forbid direct diagonal or cross-links:\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[1,3]],\n\n  num_anc: 4,                   # two Bell analyzers \u00d7 two detectors each\n  num_pre: 1,\n\n  # We postselect on a two-photon detection at the diagonal corners A=0 and C=2\n  out_nodes: [0,2],\n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],\n\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n  \u2022 Four PDC sources create entangled pairs on edges A\u2013B (modes 0,1), B\u2013C (1,2), C\u2013D (2,3), D\u2013A (3,0).  \n  \u2022 Two linear-optical Bell-state analyzers (50:50 BS + photon counters) at B and D mix the adjacent-edge photons, each with a static phase-shifter \u03c6\u2093 on the A \u2192 B and C \u2192 D links and \u03c6\u1d67 on the B \u2192 C and D \u2192 A links.  \n  \u2022 Successful clicks on all four ancilla detectors herald that only the two diagonal corner photons (modes 0 and 2) remain.  \n  \u2022 Postselecting on those two corner detections yields the Bell correlation \u222300\u27e9+e^{i(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67)}\u222311\u27e9.  Scanning \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67 from 0\u21922\u03c0 gives a \u03c0-phase jump at \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67=\u03c0\u2014a direct photonic witness of the second-order corner state (Wilson\u2010loop = \u03c0) of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nGeneralization:\n  Extend to larger M\u00d7N plaquettes or higher-order loops by adding more PDC sources and swap analyzers. Four sequential Bell\u2010swap analyzers:\n   \u2013 Analyzer_AB mixes modes (0,1) \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald swap along AB.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_BC mixes (1,2) \u2192 D\u2083,D\u2084 herald BC.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_CD mixes (2,3) \u2192 D\u2085,D\u2086 herald CD.  \n   \u2013 Analyzer_DA mixes (3,0) \u2192 D\u2087,D\u2088 herald DA.  \n   Each analyzer is a 50:50 BS with adjustable r (the same BS that implements swapping) and two photon\u2010counters.  \n5. After four successful ancilla clicks, the reference qubit at R and the teleported qubit return to mode A if the network is in the trivial phase (r\u2081>r\u2082), or remain localized at D and B if in the topological phase (r\u2081<r\u2082)\u2014corner\u2010state localization of entanglement.  \n6. Final parity readout:\n   \u2013 We perform a Bell\u2010parity analyzer on modes [4,0] (R\u2013A) and another on [4,2] (R\u2013C) in separate runs.  \n   \u2013 In the trivial regime one finds high R\u2013A fidelity; in the topological regime (r\u2081<r\u2082) R\u2013A fidelity collapses and R\u2013C (or R\u2013D) fidelity peaks\u2014directly witnessing the emergence of a corner state.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement\u2010pumping corner\u2010state network \u2192 simulate BBH quadrupole model via alternating BS reflectivities & detect corner\u2010state localization\",\n  foldername: \"ent_pump_corner\",\n  single_emitters: [],\n\n  #     "output": "Here is a Pytheus\u2010compatible proposal for a genuinely new quantum\u2010network experiment\u2014no static state\u2010generation\u2014that we call the \u201cSuperposed-Swap Mach\u2013Zehnder\u201d network.  It uses two parallel, heralded entanglement-swap channels around the sides of a 2\u00d72 plaquette to nonlocally measure the discrete Wilson-loop phase \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67 of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian and exhibits a sharp \u03c0\u2013phase \u201ccorner flip\u201d at \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67=\u03c0, which is the hallmark of a second-order topological corner state.\n\nExplanation of the protocol  \n1. Label four spatial modes/corners:  \n   \u2022 A \u2261 mode 0: single\u2010photon input qubit  \n   \u2022 B-leg PDC\u2081 \u2192 modes [1,2] implements the A\u2192B edge swap  \n   \u2022 D-leg PDC\u2082 \u2192 modes [3,4] implements the A\u2192D edge swap  \n   \u2022 C \u2261 recombination corner, modes 2 and 4 feed the final beamsplitter  \n\n2. Input splitting: a 50:50 BS (BS_in) mixes mode 0 with vacuum and emits two arms:  \n   \u2013 Arm AB \u2192 goes to the Bell-swap at B  \n   \u2013 Arm AD \u2192 goes to the Bell-swap at D  \n\n3. Static phases \u03c6\u2093 and \u03c6\u1d67:  \n   \u2013 Impose \u03c6\u2093 on the AB arm before it meets PDC\u2081\u2019s first photon  \n   \u2013 Impose \u03c6\u1d67 on the AD arm before it meets PDC\u2082\u2019s first photon  \n\n4. Heralded swaps:  \n   \u2013 Bell-state analyzer at B: 50:50 BS mixes the AB arm (post \u03c6\u2093) with PDC\u2081 mode 1 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald successful A\u2192B swap  \n   \u2013 Bell-state analyzer at D: 50:50 BS mixes the AD arm (post \u03c6\u1d67) with PDC\u2082 mode 3 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2083,D\u2084 herald successful A\u2192D swap  \n\n5. After both heralds, the unmeasured partners PDC\u2081\u2010mode 2 and PDC\u2082\u2010mode 4 are the two teleportation outputs.  \n\n6. Final interference at C:  \n   \u2013 A second 50:50 BS (BS_out) mixes modes 2 & 4 \u2192 output detectors O\u2081,O\u2082  \n   \u2013 Postselect on exactly one photon click (either O\u2081 or O\u2082) **and** all four ancilla clicks.  \n\n7. Measured observable:  \n   \u2013 The conditional probability difference P(O\u2081)\u2212P(O\u2082) \u221d cos(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67).  \n   \u2013 Scanning \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67 from 0\u21922\u03c0 yields an interference fringe with a **\u03c0\u2013phase jump** at \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67=\u03c0.  \n   \u2013 This abrupt flip is the photonic signature of a second\u2010order topological corner state (the discrete Wilson-loop = \u03c0) of the simulated Bloch Hamiltonian.  \n\nBecause the input photon never visits C until after two independent heralded swaps, and because we recombine the two teleportation paths coherently, this network goes beyond any single\u2010swap or simple two\u2010swap fidelity scan.  It\u2019s a **Mach\u2013Zehnder** of teleportation channels, nonlocally encoding the plaquette\u2019s Bloch Hamiltonian Wilson\u2010loop into an entanglement-swapping interferometer.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton  \n```json\n{\n  \"description\": \"Superposed-swap Mach\u2013Zehnder network \u2192 Wilson-loop \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67 & corner-state \u03c0-flip\",\n  \"foldername\": \"swap_MZI_corner\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0],            # mode 0: single-photon input\n  # Two probabilistic PDC sources:\n  #   PDC1 \u2192 [1,2] (edge A\u2013B), PDC2 \u2192 [3,4] (edge A\u2013D)\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,4],[1,3],[2,4]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                      # D\u2081\u2026D\u2084 for the two Bell analyzers\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0],\n  \"out_nodes\": [2,4],                # modes feeding BS_out\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"10\",\"01\"],     # single-photon in [2,4] \u2192 heralded router\n  \"phases\": [\"phi_x on AB arm\",\"phi_y on AD arm\"],\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"tries_per_edge\": 5,\n  \"thresholds\": [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n```\n\nVisual layout  \n```\n      mode 0                                       single-photon\n        \u2193                                         emitter\n      BS_in                       |             |\n   |         Analyzer_D\u2020                |         Analyzer_B\u2020\n\u03c6\u2093  |       (D\u2083\u2013D\u2084)                     |       (D\u2081\u2013D\u2082)\n   |           |                         |             |\n   \u2198           \u2199                         \u2198             \u2199\n   mode 2 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 BS_out \u2500\u2500 O\u2081,O\u2082 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 mode 4\n                   |\n          P(O\u2081)\u2212P(O\u2082) \u221d cos(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67)\n                   \u2193\n         \u03c0-phase jump at \u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67=\u03c0 \n        \u2190 topological corner state \u2192\n```\n\nGeneralizations  \n\u2013 Replace the square with larger plaquettes (3\u00d73, etc.) by adding more PDC sources and swap analyzers; build higher-order entanglement-interferometer loops.  \n\u2013 Use multi-port beam splitters to simulate multi-band Bloch Hamiltonians and measure higher Chern or quadrupole invariants via analogous multi-arm teleportation interferometers.  \n\u2013 Combine with time-bin or frequency encoding to probe synthetic dimensions.\n\nWhy this is new & feasible  \n\u2013 Novelty: **no existing** Pytheus example coherently superposes two separate entanglement-swap routes and recombines them in a Mach\u2013Zehnder geometry to directly read a discrete Wilson-loop phase and its \u03c0-corner-state signature.  \n\u2013 Feasibility: uses only abstract qubits, probabilistic photon-pair sources, static phase shifters, linear-optical Bell analyzers, and number-resolving detectors.  No dynamic feedback, no hyper- or hybrid-entanglement, no cavities\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s current capabilities."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Integrated quantum communication network and vibration sensing in\n  optical fibers\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Telecom Quantum Photonic Interface for a $^{40}$Ca$^+$ Single-Ion\n  Quantum Memory\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"bloch hamiltonian\" and \"corner state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Build a Bell\u2010pair chain on the four edges and perform entanglement swaps in a loop so that the final 4 photons at the corners emerge in a GHZ state. Correlations in that GHZ encode the existence of topological corner modes.\n    2. The fidelity of the teleportation reveals the Zak phase around the plaquette.\n    3. High\u2010dimensional entanglement swapping to entangle two \u201ccorner\u201d momentum eigenmodes (e.g. (0,0) and (\u03c0,\u03c0)) of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian, via two Bell pairs on the edges of the Brillouin zone. We generate four Bell\u2010pair sources on the edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A). At each of the four edge junctions we perform a Bell\u2010state measurement (using linear optics) on one photon from each adjacent pair. Conditioned on successful joint detections at those four ancilla detectors, the remaining one photon in each of A,B,C,D emerges projected into the GHZ state |0000>+|1111>. This cyclic swapping realizes a \u201ccorner\u2010to\u2010corner\u201d nonlocal correlation pattern that directly encodes the second\u2010order topological invariant of the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nConfiguration skeleton (to hand off to Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"4\u2010node GHZ by cyclic entanglement swapping \u2192 corner states of a 2D topological Bloch Hamiltonian\",\n  foldername: \"GHZ_corner_bloch\",\n  num_anc: 4,             # one ancilla detector per edge swap\n  num_pre: 1,\n  single_emitters: [],    # using probabilistic PDC sources\n  removed_connections: [  # forbid any PDC source from linking non\u2010adjacent corners directly\n    [0,2], [1,3]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: ['0000','1111'],  # GHZ on modes A,B,C,D\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n\n   Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n     source1             source2\n     \u2198   \u2199               \u2198   \u2199\n      A   B             B   C\n       \\ /                 \\\n        \u2020  Bell measure     \u2020  Bell measure\n       / \\                 /\n      D   A             C   D\n     \u2197   \u2196               \u2197   \u2196\n  Bell\u2013pair PDC      Bell\u2013pair PDC\n   source4             source3\n\nAfter the four Bell measurements (\u2020), modes A,B,C,D collapse into |0000>+|1111>. No single\u2010step GHZ is generated\u2014just Bell pairs and swaps.\n    3) Ancilla\u2010merged double\u2010swap: directly swap entanglement from corner A to D with a single 4\u2010photon interference stage (merging two Bell measurements) to minimize ancilla. By viewing the two\u2010swap channel as a loop in quasimomentum space, one can associate a Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson\u2010loop phase to different path orderings\u2014opening a new class of networks probing second\u2010order topology.\n  Step 5: Feasible: only requires three Bell\u2010pair sources, two ancilla Bell\u2010measurements (one per swap), linear optics, and post\u2010selection. Cyclic 4-swap GHZ loop on the four corners of a square plaquette \u2192 reduces to state generation (no).\n    2. Two-path entanglement-swap interferometer around the square whose heralded fidelity \u221dcos(\u03c6\u2093+\u03c6\u1d67) (too close to existing two-swap scans).\n    3. It uses only probabilistic PDC sources, 50:50 beam splitters (for coherent splitting, Bell analyzers, and final recombination), static phase shifters on the two arms, and number\u2010resolving detectors. No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyperentanglement.\n\n  Step 3: Select option (2).\n\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements a Mach\u2013Zehnder of two heralded entanglement\u2010swapping channels around a synthetic 2\u00d72 plaquette.  By coherently splitting the input qubit into two swap paths and recombining at the opposite corner, the network\u2019s two\u2010ancilla\u2010click\u2013conditioned interference phase is exactly the discrete Wilson loop \u03c6\u2093\u2212\u03c6\u1d67 of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian.  At \u03c6\u2093=\u03c6\u1d67 the \u03c0\u2010phase flip signals the presence of a second\u2010order corner state\u2014something no previous Pytheus\u2010designed network has done.\n\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires:\n    \u2022 One single\u2010photon emitter (mode 0, input qubit)  \n    \u2022 Two probabilistic PDC pair sources (modes [1,2] for AB\u2010swap, [3,4] for AD\u2010swap)  \n    \u2022 Three 50:50 BS\u2019s: one at the input to split the qubit into A\u2013B vs A\u2013D arms, two for the Bell analyzers at B and D, and one final BS at C to recombine the two teleportation amplitudes.  \n    \u2022 Static phase shifters \u03c6\u2093 on the AB\u2010arm BS, \u03c6\u1d67 on the AD\u2010arm BS.  \n    \u2022 Four ancilla detectors (two per Bell analyzer) plus two output detectors at C.  \n    \u2022 Post\u2010selection on the four ancilla clicks and one click at C.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the Pytheus target for a \u201csuperposed\u2010swap Mach\u2013Zehnder\u201d network that measures a 2D Bloch\u2010Hamiltonian Wilson loop and detects its corner\u2010state \u03c0\u2010signature via heralded teleportation interference.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label spatial modes:\n  \u2022 A = mode 0: single\u2010photon input qubit (Alice)  \n  \u2022 B\u2010ancilla pair PDC1 \u2192 modes [1,2] (edge A\u2013B)  \n  \u2022 D\u2010ancilla pair PDC2 \u2192 modes [3,4] (edge A\u2013D)  \n  \u2022 C = output corner at which we recombine (modes 5 & 6 after final BS)  \n\nNetwork steps:\n1. Input splitting: a 50:50 BS (BS_in) mixes the input at mode 0 with vacuum \u2192 branches modes 0 (to AB\u2010swap circuit) and 5 (to AD\u2010swap circuit).  \n2. Phase imprint: static phase \u03c6\u2093 on the AB branch, \u03c6\u1d67 on the AD branch.  \n3. Bell\u2010state analyzer at B: a 50:50 BS mixes mode 0 (post\u2010\u03c6\u2093) with PDC1 mode 1 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald A\u2192B swap.  \n4. Bell\u2010state analyzer at D: a 50:50 BS mixes mode 5 (post\u2010\u03c6\u1d67) with PDC2 mode 3 \u2192 ancilla detectors D\u2083,D\u2084 herald A\u2192D swap.  \n5. After both heralded swaps, the two teleported amplitudes emerge in PDC1 partner mode 2 and PDC2 partner mode 4.  \n6. Output recombination: a final 50:50 BS (BS_out) mixes modes [2,4] \u2192 detectors O\u2081,O\u2082.  \n7. Post\u2010select on clicks (D\u2081..D\u2084 and exactly one click at O\u2081 or O\u2082). The relative probability P(O\u2081)\u2212P(O\u2082) \u221d cos(\u03c6\u2093\u2212\u03c6\u1d67).  At \u03c6\u2093=\u03c6\u1d67 (mod \u03c0) the interference flips sign\u2014a robust \u03c0\u2010phase jump that is the photonic witness of a second\u2010order corner state in the underlying Bloch Hamiltonian.\n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Superposed\u2010swap Mach\u2013Zehnder \u2192 Wilson\u2010loop = \u03c6\u2093\u2212\u03c6\u1d67 & corner\u2010state \u03c0\u2010jump\",\n  foldername: \"swap_MZI_corner\",\n  single_emitters: [0],             # mode 0 single\u2010photon input\n  # PDC pair sources:\n  #   PDC1 \u2192 [1,2], PDC2 \u2192 [3,4]\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,4],[1,3],[2,4]],\n  num_anc: 4,                       # D\u2081\u2026D\u2084 for the two Bell analyzers\n  num_pre: 1,\n  in_nodes: [0],\n  out_nodes: [5,6],                 # modes into BS_out\n  target_quantum: ['10','01'],      # single photon in modes [5,6] with phase\u2010dependent distribution\n  phases: ['phi_x on BS_in\u2192B branch','phi_y on BS_in\u2192D branch'],\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nVisual layout:\n\n      single\u2010photon emitter\n           mode 0\n             \u2198        \u03c6\u2093\n   BS_in \u2192 0   \u2194 5       (phase)\n             \u2199          \u03c6\u1d67\n         PDC1[1\u21942]      PDC2[3\u21944]\n            |               |\n     Analyzer_B\u2020      Analyzer_D\u2020\n        D\u2081,D\u2082              D\u2083,D\u2084\n           \u2198   \u2199            \u2198   \u2199\n           mode 2           mode 4\n             \u2198   \u2199\n          BS_out \u2192 O\u2081,O\u2082\n\n\u2020 = Bell\u2010state analyzers (BS + two ancilla detectors each)\n\nBy scanning \u03c6\u2093\u2212\u03c6\u1d67, the heralded teleportation interference parity flips at \u03c6\u2093=\u03c6\u1d67 (\u03c0\u2010jump), giving a direct photonic witness of the second\u2010order corner state of a 2D Bloch Hamiltonian.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: We need a network-only Pytheus target (no pure state generation) that ties together a Bloch Hamiltonian and its \u201ccorner state\u201d into an entanglement-swapping/teleportation protocol.  \nStep 2: I propose a \u201ctopological entanglement tomography\u201d on a 2\u00d72 plaquette: start with a reference Bell pair between R and corner A, then perform four sequential Bell-swap measurements around the square (edges AB, BC, CD, DA) whose beam-splitter reflectivities alternate (r\u2081 on AB & CD, r\u2082 on BC & DA) to simulate the BBH quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian.  At the end we measure R\u2019s correlation with each corner (A, B, C, D) in separate runs.  Sweeping (r\u2081,r\u2082) yields a two-dimensional entanglement\u2010map: in the trivial regime entanglement remains at A; in the topological regime it \u201cpumps\u201d onto the opposite corner C (or D/B), directly witnessing the fractional corner state.  This network can be generalized to larger lattices, multi\u2010step loops, and higher\u2010order invariants.  \nStep 3: Novelty: Pytheus has never designed a network that 1) simulates a 2D quadrupole Bloch Hamiltonian via alternating-coupling Bell swaps, and 2) tomographically maps entanglement onto all four corners to detect corner localization.  \nStep 4: Feasibility: uses one reference PDC source, four link PDC sources, four static-reflectivity BS\u2019s as Bell analyzers, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics, probabilistic sources, and no-feedback capabilities.  \nStep 5: This idea yields a convincing theory paper: it opens a family of \u201centanglement-pump\u201d networks probing higher-order topology purely via measured correlations.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\n{\n  description: \"Topological entanglement tomography on a 2\u00d72 plaquette \u2192 simulate BBH quadrupole model by sequential Bell swaps with alternating couplings and map corner-state entanglement\",\n  foldername: \"topo_ent_tomo\",\n  single_emitters: [],\n  # Photon-pair sources:\n  #   REF \u2192 [4,0]     (R\u2013A reference Bell pair)\n  #   AB  \u2192 [0,1]     (edge A\u2013B, reflectivity r1)\n  #   BC  \u2192 [1,2]     (edge B\u2013C, reflectivity r2)\n  #   CD  \u2192 [2,3]     (edge C\u2013D, reflectivity r1)\n  #   DA  \u2192 [3,0]     (edge D\u2013A, reflectivity r2)\n  removed_connections: [[4,1],[4,2],[4,3]],\n  # Four Bell analyzers on edges AB, BC, CD, DA:\n  num_anc: 8,              # two detectors per analyzer\n  num_pre: 1,\n  reflectivities: [\"r1 on AB & CD\",\"r2 on BC & DA\"],\n  # In each corner-tomography run we read out R\u2013X parity for X\u2208{A=0,B=1,C=2,D=3}:\n  # target_quantum is the subspace of correlated clicks on [4,X]:\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  # The Expert will perform four separate Pytheus optimizations, each with out_nodes:[4,X],\n  # scanning (r1,r2) to map the entanglement distribution.\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}"
